newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: OPPOSITION CALLS FOR FASTER S.AFRICA PRIVATISATION.
newsitem.headline: OPPOSITION CALLS FOR FASTER S.AFRICA PRIVATISATION.

text.p: A vigorous privatisation programme was on Tuesday mooted in parliament by several speakers, including Inkatha Freedom Party leader Mangosutho Buthelezi, as the best way to reduce debt and boost growth.
Speaking during the debate on the 1997/98 budget, Buthelezi said that government had to adopt tough, courageous and principled policies.
"When necessary we must also have the determination to propose and implement unpopular policies which might call for sacrifices," he said.

"If government wants to achieve its six percent growth rate target by the end of the decade, we cannot just do more of the same. What is needed is a momentous impulse in three directions -- privatisation, deregulation and unemployment."

Privatisation would help reduce debt and increase the overall efficiency of the economic system. Deregulation should become a new culture of government. Taxation had to be lowered and tax collection could partly be privatised, he said.

Democratic Party finance spokesman Ken Andrew said that despite the commitment of President Nelson Mandela to privatisation, there had been "clumsy and half-hearted attempts" at selling off state assets.
These had cost South Africa dearly as it lost out on the benefits of debt reduction, greater efficiency, technology transfer and new investments as well as job creation.

Andrew estimated that a vigorous privatisation exercise could raise 20 billion rand in 1997/98. That would slash government's borrowing requirement from the 37 billion rand estimated in the budget to 17 billion rand which would push interest rates down significantly.
Growth would be boosted and exchange controls could be abolished altogether because of improved foreign reserves, he said.
Higher growth would, in turn, attract large sums of foreign investment. "It sounds too good to be true, but it is not," he said.
